RSF claimed they had killed more than 1000 of the Joint forces soldiers and captured hundreds of military vehicles (fatalities uncorroborated). RSF killed SAF captives. 358 households were displaced. Fatalities coded as 73 (5 + 8 civilians + 60 RSF).

source: Al Jazeera; Al Mashhad Al Sudani; Al Rakoba News; Al Sudani; Al Taghyeer (Sudan); Alhamish Voice; Beam reports; Darfur 24; Darfur Women Action; ECHO; GCR2P; Guardian; Radio Dabanga; Reuters; SAPA; Save the Children; SIHA; Sudan News Agency; Sudan Tribune; Sudan War Monitor; Sudan War Updates; Twitter; Wakalat; Yale School of Public Health
notes: On 13 April 2025, clashes between RSF, backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), and SAF, backed by Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF, continued in Zamzam IDP camp (Al Fasher, North Darfur), with exchange of artillery shelling. RSF overtook the area. RSF burned large parts of the camp. The Joint forces claimed they have wounded 70 RSF soldiers and destroyed 40 military vehicles. RSF claimed they have deployed troops to secure medical and aid workers and accused the Joint forces of using the IDPs camp as military camp. RSF tied and burned 14 women alive. 100,000 - 400,000 people were displaced while 400 people were reported missing, and both RSF and Joint forces were accused of preventing the IDPs from fleeing. 1,200 were abducted mostly men aged between 15-50. 47 rape cases targeted women and girls. Between 11 - 13 April, 300 - 500 civilians were killed in El Fasher, Zamzam IDPs Camp, and Abu Shouk IDPs Camp, 152 remaining fatalities split between 9 events in 3 days in these locations, 17 fatalities coded to this event.

source: Al Jazeera; Al Mashhad Al Sudani; Al Rakoba; Al Rakoba News; Al Sudani; Al Taghyeer (Sudan); Alhamish Voice; Alnilin; AP; Asharq News Sudan; Ayin Network; Beam reports; Darfur 24; Darfur Women Action; GCR2P; IOM; JSAMF Darfur; Madameek; Radio Dabanga; Radio Tamazuj; Rapid Support Forces; Sudan News; Sudan News Agency; Sudan Tribune; Sudan War Monitor; Sudan War Updates; The Middle East Journal; Twitter; UN RC/HC Sudan; UNOCHA; WikiLeaks - El Fasher 'Darfur News'; Xinhua; Yale School of Public Health
notes: On 20 March 2025, clashes between RSF backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), and SAF backed by Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF, continued in and around Malha (Al Malha, North Darfur), with SAF airstrikes, RSF strategic fighter drones, and artillery shelling. RSF controlled the city after the Joint Forces withdrew. The Joint Forces claimed later that they repelled RSF and regained control of the city (uncorroborated). RSF claimed they overtook the Joint Forces base, the locality building, and Central Reserve Forces base, killed 380 Joint Forces soldiers (uncorroborated), and the forces commander Abdalla Banah was wounded, released tens of civilian prisoners, and captured a large number of military vehicles and equipment. The Joint Forces claimed they repelled RSF offensives from three fronts, killed 93 RSF soldiers, including 8 commanders, wounded 77 (uncorroborated), and destroyed 4 military vehicles. Uncorroborated fatalities coded as 10 for each side. RAC denied the accusation of participating with RSF against the Joint Forces, and claimed the RAC defector factions were the ones who participated. RSF attacked civilians and killed 203, including 17 community leaders, and 63-68 were wounded in addition to 22 reported missing, and looted civilians' houses and markets on 20 March and 21 March (coded separately). 203 civilians' fatalities split across the two days and coded as 102 for this event. Fatalities coded as 122 (10 Joint forces + 10 RSF + 102 civilians). 15,000 households were displaced.

Around 19 March 2025 (as reported), 6 militants on a pickup truck (coded as Darfur communal militia) abducted a trader coming from the nearby Mawashi market (Cattel market) to Otash IDP Camp (Nyala Shimal, South Darfur).

On of the victims was abducted about two months earlier.

source: Al Arab; Al Jazeera; Beam reports; Darfur 24; Independent; Radio Dabanga; Sudan War Updates; Twitter; WikiLeaks - El Fasher 'Darfur News'; Yale School of Public Health
notes: On 2 March 2025, RSF, backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), shelled Abu Shouk IDP Camp (Al Fasher, North Darfur). 4-6 civilians were killed and 11 were wounded.

Weapons seizure: Around 2 March 2025 (as reported), SAF took over a building containing RSF weapons in the western sector of Omdurman (unclear if in western Um Bada locality or in western Omdurman city, location coded to state capital Khartoum, Khartoum, Khartoum).

source: Al Arab; Al Jazeera; Al Rakoba; Al Rakoba News; Alhamish Voice; Beam reports; Darfur 24; Darfur Network for Monitoring and Documentation; IOM; Radio Dabanga; Sudan News; Sudan News Agency; Sudan Tribune; Sudan War Monitor; Twitter; WikiLeaks - El Fasher 'Darfur News'
notes: On 1 March 2025, RSF, backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), on 170 military vehicles attacked civilians and pastoralists in 52 villages in Dar As Salam locality (location coded to locality capital Dar El Salam, North Darfur). The RSF burned houses, looted cattle and markets. Thousands were displaced. 15-20 civilians were killed in 52 villages coded to 12 locations, fatalities split over 13 locations. Fatalities coded as 2 for this event. A report mentioned that women were raped during the attack. 4,684 households were displaced from Abu Dewail A, Goz Baina, Keliba, Ketir Ghanie, Yahya Bedie, Sabur Dafalla, Abu Noureen, Dagaga, Um Ghebaisha Shamal, Um Ghebaisha Janoub, Um Zafaya, Um Debeiba, Hillat Hassan, Abu Gurn, Salogie, Agto, Um Melimah, Hillat Abd Al-Rasoul, Jaour, Um Semeima, and Um Hashaba villages, in addition to 2,653 households were displaced from Hillat Abdalla Mustafa, Um Arada, Abaker Khashim Alsokar, Ismail Badawi, Um Redim, Gherawet Basham, Sanana, Raida, Kenbie, Um Dorni, Banat Shariq, Banat Kharib, and Hillat Khazan villages.

Shugara forces captured 2 RSF military vehicles. 77-150 people were killed and others were wounded across two days (coded separately). 77 fatalities split across two days and coded as 38 for this event. 30 households were displaced.

Around 25 January 2025 (as reported), RSF abducted 37 miners from Adila and Abu Karinka localities in East Darfur on their way to mining areas in SAF-controlled areas, in Gebrat Al Sheikh (Gebrat Al Sheikh, North Kordofan). RSF released them after their families paid 5 million SDG ransom.
On 25 January 2025, SAF regained control from RSF over Al Sheikhab (Shendi, River Nile) (date of initial RSF takeover unclear). It is unclear if there were clashes.
On 25 January 2025, RSF abducted a civilian in Nyala (Nyala Janoub, South Darfur), after he was accused of collaborating with SAF. Extent of injuries unknown/not reported.

On 24 January 2025, clashes between SAF and RSF continued in Um Khairain Abo Gawi (Um Rawaba, North Kordofan). SAF regained control over the area (SAF lost Um Rawaba and its surrounding areas to RSF on 13 September 2023). Casualties unknown.

source: AFP; Al Jazeera; Al Mashhad Al Sudani; Al Rakoba; Al Rakoba News; Al Sudani; Al Taghyeer (Sudan); Alhamish Voice; Alnilin; Beam reports; Central Committee of Sudan Doctors; Darfur 24; Darfur Network for Monitoring and Documentation; Darfur Women Action; ECHO; Erem News; Guardian; Madamasr; Madameek; Radio Dabanga; Reuters; Sudan Akhbar; Sudan INGO; Sudan News Agency; Sudan Now Magazine; Sudan Tribune; Sudan War Monitor; Sudan War Updates; Twitter; UN HRC; UNOCHA; UNSG; Wakalat; WikiLeaks - El Fasher 'Darfur News'; Xinhua
notes: On 24 January 2025, clashes between RSF, backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), and SAF, backed by Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF, continued in 5 frontlines in El Fasher (Al Fasher, North Darfur), with SAF airstrikes, RSF fighter drones, and exchange of artillery shelling. RSF deployed reinforcement coming from Libya. The Joint forces claimed they killed 400 RSF soldiers (fatalities uncorroborated and coded as 10), including RSF commander Abdelrahman Jomaa Mansour, wounded 750 and captured 150 soldiers, destroyed 30-70 military vehicles, and captured 25 vehicles. RSF stormed Shala prison and released some RSF prisoners. RSF strategic fighter drone targeted Saudi hospital and 67-70 civilians were killed and 19-100 were wounded, in addition to 17-20 civilians killed and 15 wounded during the clashes. Fatalities coded as 94 (10 RSF + 67 civilians + 17 civilians).

Movement of forces: Around 24 January 2025 (between 24 January - 25 January), an unspecified number of RSF left Hajj Yusuf (Sharg An Neel, Khartoum) following SAF reinforcements' arrival to SAF Signals Corps and General Command HQ in Khartoum (coded separately).

source: Darfur Women Action; WikiLeaks - El Fasher 'Darfur News'
notes: On 24 January 2025, RSF, backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), shelled Abu Shouk IDP Camp (Al Fasher, North Darfur). 8-19 IDPs were killed and 20 were wounded.

notes: Movement of forces: On 24 January 2025, SAF forces arrived in the SAF Signal Corps in Khartoum North - Kobar (Bahri, Khartoum), joining the Corps forces and breaking a siege imposed on the corps by RSF for 21 months.

Around 24 January 2025 (as reported), RSF tortured a doctor after abducting him from an unspecified location in Khartoum state (location coded to capital Khartoum, Khartoum, Khartoum). Extent of injuries unknown/not reported.

source: Al Mashhad Al Sudani; Al Rakoba; Beam reports; Darfur 24; Radio Dabanga; Sudan News Agency; Sudan Tribune; Sudan War Updates; Twitter; WikiLeaks - El Fasher 'Darfur News'
notes: On 23 January 2025, clashes between RSF, backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), and SAF, backed by Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF, continued in El Fasher (Al Fasher, North Darfur), with SAF fighter jets and drones strikes, anti-aircraft missile, and RSF strategic fighter drones, in addition to the exchange of artillery shelling. The Joint Forces shot down 6 RSF fighter drones. The Joint forces claimed they killed 63 RSF soldiers and destroyed 17-45 military vehicles. 9 RSF surrendered to the Joint forces. 2 civilians were killed and 4 were wounded. A report mentioned that tens of SAF joined RSF on the eastern front due to a dispute with their commander. Fatalities coded as 65 (63 RSF + 2 civilians).

On 23 January 2025, an RSF soldier beat a civilian, who responded by hitting the soldier with a stone in his head in Nyala (Nyala Janoub, South Darfur). The soldier died of his wounds, and the extent of the civilian injuries unknown/not reported. Additionally, three RSF soldiers abducted and beat with gun butt a civilian. His whereabouts are unknown/not reported.
